questions.explanation: When riding, you should choose pants and a jacket made of leather or another sturdy material. They should fit you snugly enough that they do not flap in the wind, but also loosely enough that they let you move freely.

questions.question: Which material provides the best protection in the case of a crash?
questions.answerC: Wool
questions.explanation: Clothing made of sturdy leather or synthetic materials provide riders the best protection in the case of an accident. Riders should wear long pants and jackets while riding.

questions.question: The oily strip down the center of a lane:
questions.answerA: Should only be traveled upon if you are sharing the lane with another vehicle.
questions.answerB: Usually provides adequate traction for riding, unless it is raining.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided at all times.
questions.explanation: While the center strip of the road can be oily, it usually provides enough traction for safe riding, unless it is raining. The oily strip is usually no more than two feet wide, so motorcyclists can generally ride on either side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should be sure not to:
questions.answerA: Keep their knees against the gas tank while riding.
questions.answerB: Keep their feet firmly on the footrests while riding.
questions.answerC: Adjust the handlebars so their hands are above their elbows.
questions.explanation: Adjust the handlebars so your hands are even with or below your elbows. This positioning allows you to use the proper muscles for precision steering. Keep your feet on the footrests and your knees against the gas tank to help you maintain your balance when turning.

questions.question: The control for the front brake lever is usually located:
questions.answerC: On both handle grips.
questions.explanation: The front brake level is usually located on the right handle grip. Make sure you know where all of your motorcycle's controls are before beginning to ride.

questions.question: When riding, jackets and pants should:
questions.answerA: Fit loosely enough to allow the wind to catch the fabric.
questions.answerB: Be snug enough to keep from flapping in the wind.
questions.answerC: Be tight enough to prevent you from moving freely.
questions.explanation: Jackets and pants should fit snugly enough that they do not flap in the wind, but also loosely enough that you are able to move freely.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection:
questions.answerC: Should only be done by a certified mechanic.
questions.explanation: You should do a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of ____ is considered intoxicated.
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: In Virginia, a person with a blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered intoxicated. Any intoxicated person is prohibited from operating a motor vehicle.

questions.question: To shift up to a higher gear, you must:
questions.answerA: Place your foot under the shift lever and lift.
questions.answerB: Place your foot over the shift lever and push.
questions.answerC: Use your thumb to move the lever.
questions.explanation: To shift up to a higher gear, position your foot under the shift lever and lift.

questions.question: As your motorcycle increases speed, you will:
questions.answerA: Need to shift up through the gears.
questions.answerB: Need to shift down through the gears.
questions.answerC: Need to put the motorcycle into neutral.
questions.explanation: It is necessary to shift into higher gears as your motorcycle increases its speed.

questions.question: Lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are separated by:
questions.answerC: Road signs.
questions.explanation: White lines are used to separate traffic moving in the same direction. Solid lines indicate that drivers are not permitted to pass, whereas dashed lines indicate that drivers are permitted to pass, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You are most likely to get into a collision:
questions.answerC: Traveling on the expressway.
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between you and other traffic exists at intersections.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best formation for keeping riders together while maintaining adequate space cushions is generally:
questions.answerC: A staggered formation.
questions.explanation: In general, the best way for a group of motorcyclists to maintain close ranks while still allowing each rider an adequate space cushion is to ride in a staggered formation.

questions.question: To minimize the potential for fatigue, you should:
questions.answerC: Drink caffeine.
questions.explanation: Taking frequent rest breaks during a long trip can help reduce fatigue. Stimulants, such as caffeine, can ultimately increase the danger of fatigue because you may become extremely tired when they begin to wear off. Wind, rain, snow, and other elements can also increase levels of fatigue, so dress warmly (as needed) and invest in a windshield, especially if you plan to ride long distances.

questions.question: Hearing protection:
questions.answerA: Is not needed when the rider is wearing a helmet.
questions.answerB: Is only recommended for long trips.
questions.answerC: Should be used on all rides.
questions.explanation: Exposure to engine and wind noise can damage your hearing, even if you are wearing a helmet. Wearing hearing protection while riding is always a good idea.

questions.question: Whichever style of helmet you choose, you will get the most protection by ensuring that your helmet:
questions.answerC: Looks cool.
questions.explanation: You will get the maximum protection from your helmet if it meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards, fits snugly all the way around, and has no obvious defects.

questions.question: If you approach an uncontrolled intersection at the same time as another vehicle:
questions.answerA: The vehicle on the left should yield to the vehicle on the right.
questions.answerB: You should flash your headlight to signal that the other vehicle should proceed.
questions.answerC: You should continue through the intersection and expect the other vehicle to stop.
questions.explanation: If you approach an intersection that is not marked with signs or traffic lights at the same time as another driver, the driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right.

questions.question: If riding during the day, you should wear:
questions.answerA: Brightly-colored clothing to increase your chances of being seen.
questions.answerB: Clothing of any color because other drivers can easily see you in daylight.
questions.answerC: Darkly-colored clothing to contrast with the bright sunlight.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes take place in broad daylight. You should always wear brightly-colored clothing to increase your visibility while riding, even during the day.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a benefit of maintaining a space cushion between your motorcycle and other vehicles?
questions.answerA: You will have time to react to hazards.
questions.answerB: You will have space to maneuver.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to accelerate when entering a curve.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times helps ensure that you will have time to react and space to maneuver if someone else on the road makes a mistake.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerA: Move your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders, to look through the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and shoulders to look through the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon. Turning your shoulders may cause you to steer off course.

questions.question: When you are stopped, you should:
questions.answerC: Stay in second gear.
questions.explanation: It is recommended that riders stay in first gear when they come to a stop. Remaining in first gear allows riders the ability to quickly move out of the way if a hazard arises.

questions.question: A person with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of ____ is considered intoxicated.
questions.answerC: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: In Virginia, a person with a blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered intoxicated. Any intoxicated person is prohibited from operating a motor vehicle.

questions.question: To reduce the chances of a collision, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Stare straight in front of their motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Be unwilling to move to avoid a potential hazard.
questions.answerC: Scan their path of travel, looking at least 10 to 15 seconds ahead of their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a collision, consistently scan your path of travel at least 10 to 15 seconds ahead of your motorcycle. Scanning the road ahead will give you time to react to a hazard before meeting the hazard.

questions.question: When riding in the rain, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride down the center of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride on the right side of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in tire tracks left by other cars.
questions.explanation: A road is often very slippery when rain first begins to fall. When it starts to rain, ride in the tire tracks left by cars to get the best traction.

questions.question: If using saddlebags to carry a load, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the bags as evenly as possible.
questions.answerB: Unevenly distribute weight into the saddlebags.
questions.answerC: Place as much weight as possible into one saddlebag.
questions.explanation: Saddlebags should be loaded with approximately equal weights. If a load is distributed unevenly between bags, it may cause the motorcycle to drift to one side.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to be seen.
questions.answerC: Invite other road users into your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When riding ________, you are facing the greatest potential for conflict between you and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: In a group
questions.explanation: Intersections present the greatest potential for conflict between motorcycles and other vehicles. When approaching an intersection, be sure you are riding in a lane position that makes you most visible to other road users.

questions.question: When carrying a load, it should be:
questions.answerC: Secured on a sissy bar.
questions.explanation: Loads should be secured low in order to avoid upsetting the motorcycle's balance.

questions.question: When buying a motorcycle helmet, you should be most concerned about the helmet's:
questions.answerC: Appearance.
questions.explanation: Protection should be your first consideration when buying a motorcycle helmet.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerC: No U-turn
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs are white signs with red and black markings that inform drivers of specific traffic laws in the indicated area. This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited.

questions.question: When being followed by a tailgater, you should:
questions.answerC: Not change how you are riding.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to allow them to pass you. Speeding up may result in them continuing to tailgate you, just at a higher speed.

questions.question: Smaller vehicles appear to be ________ and slower than they really are.
questions.answerC: Larger
questions.explanation: It can be difficult to judge the speed and distance of a small vehicle, such as a motorcycle. Do not assume that drivers of larger vehicles will be able to accurately understand your speed and location.

questions.question: When motorcyclists ride in a group:
questions.answerA: Inexperienced riders should lead the group.
questions.answerB: Inexperienced riders should be near the front of the group.
questions.answerC: Inexperienced riders should be in the back of the group.
questions.explanation: When traveling in a group, less experienced riders should be placed near the front of the group behind the leader. This way, more experienced riders can lead the way and watch the inexperienced riders at the same time.

questions.question: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should:
questions.answerC: Follow other vehicles closely.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: When being passed, you should ride in:
questions.answerA: The left portion of your lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of your lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side of the lane nearest the passing driver increases the danger of colliding with them, and riding on the side farthest from the driver may tempt them to return to your lane too soon.

questions.question: A sign that your rear tire has suddenly gone flat is that:
questions.answerA: The back of your motorcycle is swaying from side to side.
questions.answerC: A discharge of air can be seen.
questions.explanation: If the rear tire of a motorcycle goes flat, the back of the motorcycle may jerk or sway from side to side. If you experience this movement when riding your motorcycle, you should stop riding and check your tires as soon as possible.

questions.question: How should you brake?
questions.answerC: With both brakes
questions.explanation: Use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Who is required to wear a helmet on a moving motorcycle?
questions.answerC: No one
questions.explanation: All riders and passengers are required to wear a helmet when riding a motorcycle, motor-driven cycle, or motorized bicycle.

questions.question: When positioning your body on the motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You should hold yourself up with your arms.
questions.answerB: Your arms should be used to steer the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: You should have to stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: To have proper riding posture, position yourself so that you are using your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. Sit so that your elbows are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, traveling in the center portion of the lane:
questions.answerA: Allows you to be seen in its rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Usually makes it difficult for the driver to see you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided.
questions.explanation: When following a car, you should ride in a position that allows the driver to see you in their rearview mirror. Usually, that means riding in the center portion of the lane. Because most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than they check their side mirrors, being in this lane position increases the chance that they will see you.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be:
questions.answerC: In the rear.
questions.explanation: In a group, less experienced riders should be positioned toward the front, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to watch them from behind.

questions.question: Under normal conditions, a motorcyclist should maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists should maintain a minimum two-second following distance under normal conditions. Any time conditions are less than perfect, a larger following distance is recommended.

questions.question: Most motorcycle/automobile accidents occur:
questions.answerC: In parking lots.
questions.explanation: Most collisions between motorcycles and automobiles take place at intersections. The most common cause of these accidents is the automobile operator failing to properly yield the right-of-way to the motorcyclist.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.answerC: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: To improve your chances of being seen, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your headlight only at night or when conditions reduce visibility.
questions.answerC: Add an orange tint to your headlight.
questions.explanation: The single most effective thing you can do to help others see your motorcycle is ride with your headlight on at all times.

questions.question: If you accidentally lock your rear brake on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Let go of the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Keep the rear brake locked until you stop.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear tire on a good traction surface, leave it locked until you can come to a complete stop. Even with a locked rear wheel, you will be able to control a motorcycle on a surface with good traction as long as the motorcycle is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: For motorcycle operators, eye protection is:
questions.answerC: Not recommended.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle operators are required to use proper eye protection when riding in Georgia.

questions.question: A primary cause of single-vehicle motorcycle collisions is:
questions.answerA: Motorcyclists' tendency to ride too fast for weather conditions.
questions.answerB: Motorcyclists turning too wide in a curve or turn.
questions.answerC: Motorcyclists running off the road while trying to avoid a collision with another vehicle.
questions.explanation: A primary cause of single-vehicle collisions is motorcyclists running too wide in a curve or turn. Taking a turn too wide can cause a motorcycle to leave the roadway or collide with an object.

questions.question: When stopping, you should:
questions.answerC: Use the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes every time you slow or stop. It is important to be able to brake quickly by using both brakes.

questions.question: When making a non-emergency stop on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Only the front brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The front and rear brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.answerC: Only the rear brake should be used.
questions.explanation: When making a normal, non-emergency stop, use the front and rear brakes simultaneously and downshift.

questions.question: The faster you drink alcohol:
questions.answerA: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol accumulates in your body.
questions.answerC: The less the alcohol affects your body.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the faster the alcohol will accumulate in your body. Alcohol leaves a person's system at an average of one drink per hour. If you consume more than one drink in an hour, you will still have alcohol in your body after one hour has passed.

questions.question: When wearing a jacket for protection, the jacket should:
questions.answerA: Be loose-fitting and flap in the wind while riding.
questions.answerC: Be uncomfortable.
questions.explanation: Clothing for riding should provide protection while keeping you comfortable. Jackets and pants should be snug enough that they do not flap in the wind, but not so snug that they restrict your movements.

questions.question: Before a ride, a motorcycle operator should check the throttle. The throttle should:
questions.answerC: Snap back when released.
questions.explanation: Check your clutch and throttle before riding your motorcycle. The throttle should snap back when you let go and the clutch should feel tight and smooth.

questions.question: The best way to help others see your motorcycle is to:
questions.answerC: Wave at drivers.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do to help others see your motorcycle is to keep your headlight on at all times. Motorcycles sold in the United States after 1978 automatically have the headlight activated while running, but be sure that the headlight works properly before every ride.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between you and other vehicles?
questions.answerC: On any road
questions.explanation: The potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other vehicles is greatest at intersections.

questions.question: As you consume more alcohol, your ability to safely ride:
questions.answerC: Decreases.
questions.explanation: The skills a person needs to ride safely decrease as the amount of alcohol consumed increases. If you have consumed alcohol in any amount, it is safest not to ride your motorcycle.

questions.question: When passing a truck on a two-lane road, you should:
questions.answerA: Not return to your original lane until you can see the front of the truck in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Return to your original lane as soon as the truck is behind you.
questions.answerC: Return to your original lane when you feel you have enough space.
questions.explanation: When passing a truck, you should only return to your original lane when you can see the entire front of the truck in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: Pick a lane position that:
questions.answerB: Hides you from other road users.
questions.answerC: Places you directly next to another vehicle.
questions.explanation: Choose a lane position that helps you avoid road hazards. Make sure you maintain a safe cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: If wearing a jacket for protection while riding in hot weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Take frequent breaks to cool off.
questions.answerB: Remove the jacket to stay cool while in the sun.
questions.answerC: Keep the jacket on to protect you from the heat.
questions.explanation: A sturdy riding jacket provides essential protection in the event of a crash, no matter the weather. Jackets also provide an additional benefit in hot weather by protecting the rider against dehydration. Many motorcycling jackets are designed to prevent the wearer from overheating.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, which portion of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerC: Left
questions.explanation: When being passed, the center portion of the lane is generally the safest lane position for a motorcyclist. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with it. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle can also be dangerous because it may prompt the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: During normal turns:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle and rider should lean in the same direction.
questions.answerB: The motorcycle and rider should lean in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: The motorcycle should not lean.
questions.explanation: In a normal turn, the rider and the motorcycle should lean together at the same angle. In a slow, tight turn, the motorcycle should lean while the rider counterbalances by keeping their body upright.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, your feet should be:
questions.answerB: Pointed with your toes aiming downward.
questions.answerC: Relaxed.
questions.explanation: When riding, your feet should be kept firmly on your motorcycle's footrests for balance. Your toes should not be pointed downward, as this may cause them to get caught between the road and the footrests.

questions.question: Compared to a car, a motorcycle needs _____ attention.
questions.answerC: More frequent
questions.explanation: Compared to a car, a motorcycle requires more frequent attention. If something is wrong with a motorcycle, it is essential that the operator identify the problem before getting into traffic or operating the bike at freeway speeds.

questions.question: Before every ride, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure your bike's brake lights work properly.
questions.answerB: Make sure the paint on the bike is not peeling.
questions.answerC: Make sure your bike is completely clean.
questions.explanation: Perform safety checks before every motorcycle ride. Test your brake controls individually to make sure each one activates the brake lights.

questions.question: When stopping your motorcycle while carrying a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride a little faster than you normally would.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you normally would.
questions.answerC: Merge into smaller gaps of traffic than you normally would.
questions.explanation: A passenger places extra weight on a motorcycle. Because of the added weight, the motorcycle will respond to the operator's movements more slowly than it would otherwise, taking more time to speed up, slow down, and turn. To accommodate the change in handling when carrying a passenger, you should reduce your speed, begin slowing down earlier when you stop, and look for larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging into traffic.

questions.question: What can remove alcohol from a person's system?
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking is to give your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol. There are no techniques that will speed up this process.

questions.question: The control for the front brake lever is usually located:
questions.answerC: On both handle grips.
questions.explanation: The front brake level is usually located on the right handle grip. Make sure you know where all of your motorcycle's controls are before beginning to ride.

questions.question: When riding behind another vehicle, you should position yourself:
questions.answerA: To be seen in the vehicle’s side mirror.
questions.answerB: To be seen in the vehicle’s rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: To be seen through the vehicle's passenger window.
questions.explanation: If you are following a car, the driver is most likely to notice you if you position yourself behind them in the center of your lane. This lane position places you in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Move into the portion of the lane that will bring you into another driver’s field of vision at the earliest possible moment.
questions.answerB: Stop at the stop sign or signal and then proceed normally.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights and sound your horn to alert other drivers to your presence.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the portion of the lane that will bring you into another driver’s field of vision at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: If passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may exceed the speed limit until the pass is complete.
questions.answerB: You may disregard no passing zone markings if you began the pass in a passing zone.
questions.answerC: You must observe the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: All passes must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is permitted.

questions.question: The formation you should take when riding in a group:
questions.answerC: Is always staggered.
questions.explanation: In general, it is best for a group to ride in a staggered formation. Move into a single-file formation when taking a curve, making a turn, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: A benefit of keeping a cushion of space between you and surrounding vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You are better able to draft off of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: You will be able to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of other drivers.
questions.explanation: It is important to maintain a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times. This way, if a hazard arises, you will have more time to respond to the hazard and more space to safely maneuver.

questions.question: Eye protection:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if your motorcycle is equipped with a windshield.
questions.answerB: Is only necessary when riding in bad weather.
questions.answerC: Should allow the rider a clear view to either side.
questions.explanation: Proper face/eye protection is required by law in the state of California. A face shield can protect your whole face in the event of a collision. An effective eye or face shield must allow the rider a clear view to either side.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can protect you from:
questions.answerC: Glare.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can protect your face in the event of a crash. It also provides protection against more routine hazards, such as pebbles thrown up from other vehicles, wind, dust, dirt, rain, and insects.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Avoid making sudden moves, as doing so could cause a skid.
questions.answerB: Travel on the shoulder to be out of the way of traffic.
questions.answerC: Use only the rear brake because the front brake is ineffective on slippery surfaces.
questions.explanation: On a slippery surface, any sudden change in speed or direction could result in a skid. Be as smooth as possible when you speed up, shift gears, turn, or brake on such a surface.

questions.question: After riding over an object on the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue riding because the danger has passed.
questions.answerB: Pull to the side of the road and check your tires and rims for damage.
questions.answerC: Stop to remove the object from the road.
questions.explanation: After riding over an object on the roadway, you should pull off the road to check your tires and rims for damage before traveling any farther. Ensure that nothing is caught in the drive chain or belt before proceeding.

questions.question: You should operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch when:
questions.answerA: The throttle is stuck and you cannot free it.
questions.answerB: You start to lose control in a curve.
questions.answerC: The motorcycle starts to wobble.
questions.explanation: If the throttle becomes stuck and you are unable to free it, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time. This will remove power from the rear wheel until you are able to safely leave the road and stop.

questions.question: Oil drippings and debris often collect in ______ of a lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion
questions.explanation: Oil drippings and debris from cars and trucks often collect in the center portion of a lane.

questions.question: When entering a turn, you should:
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed before entering a turn. If you take a turn too fast, you may end up veering out of your lane or even off the road.

questions.question: To execute a turn safely, a motorcycle rider should always:
questions.answerA: Lean in the direction of the curve.
questions.answerC: Turn by using only the handle bars.
questions.explanation: When turning, you should always lean in the direction of the turn. Slow down before entering the turn.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of surviving a crash if you wear:
questions.answerC: Comfortable shoes.
questions.explanation: You will get the most head and neck protection from a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. The single most effective thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is wear a properly secured, good-quality helmet.

questions.question: If you need to react to a hazard in the road, do not:
questions.answerC: Make your presence known by sounding your horn and/or using lights or signals.
questions.explanation: To create more space and minimize the harm of any hazard, communicate your presence to other road users by using your horn, lights, and/or signals. Adjust your speed to be appropriate for the situation and adjust your lane position and/or direction of travel as needed.

questions.question: There is the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other traffic:
questions.answerC: On rural roads.
questions.explanation: Intersections present the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other vehicles. Motorcyclists should exercise caution when approaching an intersection.

questions.question: When choosing a helmet, you should ensure that it:
questions.answerC: Fits loosely.
questions.explanation: To get the best possible protection, choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects, like cracks, loose padding, and frayed straps.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerA: Vehicles will be entering the roadway.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop and proceed when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Octagonal signs that are colored red are always stop signs. When approaching one of these signs, you must come to a complete stop, yield to any other traffic or pedestrians, and proceed once it is safe to do so.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.explanation: Ride with extreme caution when approaching an intersection. Cover the clutch and both brakes to reduce your reaction time, if needed.

questions.question: When traveling at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride as fast as you would if riding during the day.
questions.answerB: Ride more slowly than you would if riding during the day.
questions.answerC: Ride faster than you would if riding during the day.
questions.explanation: When traveling at night, ride more slowly than you would if riding during the day, especially when traveling on an unfamiliar road. Riding more slowly allows you additional time to avoid hazards under conditions of decreased visibility.

questions.question: Unlike other beverages, alcohol:
questions.answerA: Is absorbed into the bloodstream right away.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t affect humans.
questions.explanation: Unlike other substances in food and drink, alcohol does not need to be digested. It is absorbed directly through the walls of the stomach and small intestine, enters the bloodstream, and quickly reaches the brain.

questions.question: The risk of a head or neck injury is reduced:
questions.answerC: By reading the owner’s manual.
questions.explanation: A head or neck injury is always a risk when riding a motorcycle, regardless of your speed of travel. With few exceptions, the risk of head and neck injuries is greatly reduced by properly wearing a quality helmet.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Only ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Vary your lane position depending on conditions.
questions.answerC: Only ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Vary your lane position as road and traffic conditions warrant.

questions.question: When consumed together, the effects of alcohol and drugs:
questions.answerA: Are less dangerous than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerC: Can be more pronounced than when either is consumed alone.
questions.explanation: Many drugs, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your ability to ride safely. Some medications become even more dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger on your motorcycle, you should instruct the passenger to:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Sit as far back as possible on the bike.
questions.answerC: Not talk or move unnecessarily.
questions.explanation: Tell passengers to avoid unnecessary conversation or movement while on a moving motorcycle. Passengers should get onto a motorcycle only after the engine is started. They should sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator.

questions.question: Locking your brakes can:
questions.answerC: Cause control problems.
questions.explanation: Locking the brakes can cause control problems. If your front brake locks, you should release the brake then immediately re-apply it. If you lock your rear brake when stopping on a good traction surface, keep it locked until you have completely stopped.

questions.question: Footrests:
questions.answerA: May be shared by the driver and passenger
questions.answerB: Are required for the driver and passenger
questions.answerC: Are not required
questions.explanation: Keep your feet firmly on the footrests for balance. The motorcycle should be equipped with passenger footrests. Firm footing prevents your passenger from falling off and pulling you off, too.

questions.question: The oily strip down the center of a lane:
questions.answerA: Should only be traveled upon if you are sharing the lane with another vehicle.
questions.answerB: Usually provides adequate traction for riding, unless it is raining.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided at all times.
questions.explanation: While the center strip of the road can be oily, it usually provides enough traction for safe riding, unless it is raining. The oily strip is usually no more than two feet wide, so motorcyclists can generally ride on either side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Service signs are:
questions.answerC: Green with white letters.
questions.explanation: Signs that are blue with white markings indicate the locations of services. These services may include rest areas, gas stations, food options, and hospitals.

questions.question: When riding at night:
questions.answerA: Only ride in the left portion of the lane to better see around other vehicles ahead.
questions.answerB: Ride closely to the vehicle in front of you to most effectively use their headlights.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed to increase your chances of avoiding an unexpected hazard.
questions.explanation: At night, you should always ride at a lower speed than you would under similar conditions during the day. Doing so will give you a better chance of avoiding hazards. Additionally, increase your following distance and be flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: There may be less traction available for braking when:
questions.answerB: A motorcycle is straight up and down.
questions.answerC: A motorcycle is on dry pavement.
questions.explanation: Any time a motorcycle is leaning, such as in a turn or curve, there is less traction available for braking. Both brakes may still be used while a motorcycle is turning, but it must be done with great care.

questions.question: A motorized bike with less than 45 cubic centimeters displacement:
questions.answerA: Cannot be operated on a public roadway.
questions.answerB: Must be operated on the shoulder .
questions.answerC: Cannot carry a passenger.
questions.explanation: In Nebraska, motorcycles, motor bikes, and motor scooters with engines of less than 45 cubic centimeters displacement, or with a total wheel and tire diameter of less than 14 inches, may not be operated on public roads.

questions.question: When nearing a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerB: Assume that other drivers will properly yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Change your lane position to become more visible to other drivers.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the lane position that makes you the most visible to surrounding drivers.

questions.question: Using all three lane positions is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged because then you can never get used to any part of a lane.
questions.answerB: Discouraged because it confuses other motorists.
questions.answerC: Wise if you are adapting to changing conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Vary your lane position as road and traffic conditions warrant.

questions.question: The key to making a quick turn is to:
questions.answerC: Get your motorcycle to lean quickly.
questions.explanation: The key to making an evasive maneuver is to get your motorcycle to quickly lean in the direction you wish to turn. The sharper the turn, the more it must lean.

questions.question: The best way to avoid fatigue when riding your motorcycle on a long trip is to:
questions.answerC: Take artificial stimulants.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued when riding your motorcycle on a long trip, limit how much time is spent riding each day and take frequent rest breaks. Avoid the use of artificial stimulants because you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: As you approach a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Move into the part of the lane that allows other drivers to most easily see you.
questions.answerB: Move into the part of the lane closest to the traffic control device.
questions.answerC: Move into the outside edge of the lane.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the portion of the lane that will bring you into any other driver's field of vision at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: Mirrors on motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Have blind spots, just like cars.
questions.answerB: Do not have blind spots because a motorcycle is usually smaller than a car
questions.answerC: Are not required.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like cars. You should always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a reason to keep a cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you?
questions.answerA: It allows you more time to respond to hazards.
questions.answerB: It prevents you from finding an escape route.
questions.answerC: It provides space to maneuver your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate space cushion ensures that you will have time to respond if another driver makes a mistake. A cushion of space also allows you the space you need to safely maneuver your motorcycle.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks up while you are stopping on a surface with good traction, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the wheel locked until you have stopped completely.
questions.answerB: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and then quickly re-apply the brake.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear wheel while stopping on a surface with good traction, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped. Even with a locked rear wheel, you can control your motorcycle if it is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: The best footwear for motorcyclists are:
questions.answerC: Sandals.
questions.explanation: Leather boots provide the greatest degree of foot protection when riding. Boots should be high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: A test of the turn signals.
questions.answerC: A paint inspection.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your motorcycle before a ride, be sure to check the tires, controls, lights, signals, mirrors, brakes, oil, fluids, chassis, and stands.

questions.question: A flat front tire is especially dangerous because:
questions.answerA: The front tire affects your steering, which also affects your balance.
questions.answerB: The front tire being flat will disable the front brake.
questions.answerC: The front tire being flat will prevent you from accelerating.
questions.explanation: A flat front tire is especially dangerous because it interferes with your ability to steer, which is essential to keeping your balance. If steering begins to feel heavy, it is possible that you have a flat front tire.

questions.question: When it starts raining, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Ride in the tire tracks left by other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When it starts to rain, avoid riding in the center of the lane. Instead, ride in the tire tracks left by cars ahead of you. The left tire track is often best for riding, but this can vary based on traffic and other conditions.

questions.question: The best way to stay out of trouble while riding a motorcycle is to:
questions.answerA: Look well ahead of your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Ride at speeds faster than the speed limit.
questions.explanation: To avoid running into dangerous situations while riding, you should consistently scan the road well ahead of your motorcycle. Watch the road ahead to identify and react to potential hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: If a dog is chasing your motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerB: Slow down, let the dog approach, and accelerate away from the animal.
questions.answerC: Park and wait for the dog to lose interest.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: When preparing to pass a vehicle on the left, you should ride in which portion of the lane?
questions.answerC: Left
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull onto the shoulder and wait for it to stop raining.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Roads become slippery when it first starts raining, especially in the center strip of a lane. When rain starts, it is generally safest to ride in the tire tracks left by other vehicles. The left tire track is often best.

questions.question: If you must transport a load, it should be:
questions.answerB: Carried on the gas tank in front of you.
questions.answerC: Piled up against a sissy bar or frame on the back of the seat.
questions.explanation: Loads should be kept over, or in front of, the rear axle. Only experienced riders should carry loads on their motorcycle.

questions.question: Riding in which lane position allows you to appear in the rearview mirror of a car ahead?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: None of the lane positions allows you to be seen.
questions.explanation: Riding in the center portion of your lane will usually place your image in the rearview mirror of a car directly ahead of you. The driver will be more likely to notice you in this lane position since most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors.

questions.question: To help others see your motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerC: Maintain eye contact with other road users.
questions.explanation: Riding with your headlight activated is the best way to help other road users see your motorcycle. Always be sure your headlight works before starting your trip.

questions.question: Stopping in a turn can be difficult because:
questions.answerA: There is decreased traction available for stopping while the bike is leaning.
questions.answerB: The rider is usually focused on the turn and not on the braking.
questions.answerC: The brake controls do not work in turns.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: To avoid confusing other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal after you complete a turn or lane change.
questions.answerC: Use your horn only in emergency situations.
questions.explanation: After completing a turn or lane change, deactivate your turn signal. Leaving your signal on after moving to the right or left can confuse other road users.

questions.question: When cars are merging from an entrance ramp:
questions.answerA: A motorcyclist should assume the entering drivers see them.
questions.answerB: A motorcyclist should never assume the entering drivers see them.
questions.answerC: A motorcyclist should stop.
questions.explanation: Always allow merging cars plenty of space and never assume that the drivers see you. Change lanes away from the entering traffic, if possible. If there is no room for a lane change, adjust your speed to allow for safe merging.

questions.question: To cross railroad tracks that run across your lane at an angle, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue riding straight within your lane.
questions.answerB: Turn within your lane to cross at a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerC: Use the shoulder to reduce your speed before crossing.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is best to simply cross while riding straight within your lane. Turning to cross the tracks at a 90-degree angle could be dangerous because you could end up crossing into another lane of traffic.

questions.question: The greatest potential for conflict between you and other road users is located:
questions.answerC: On rural roads.
questions.explanation: Intersections present the greatest potential for conflict between motorcycles and other traffic. A motorcyclist should use special caution when approaching or riding through an intersection.

questions.question: _________ of all collisions involving a motorcycle and a passenger vehicle are caused by the driver failing to yield the right-of-way to the motorcyclist.
questions.answerC: One-half
questions.explanation: More than one-half of collisions involving motorcycles and passenger vehicles are caused by drivers failing to properly yield the right-of-way to motorcyclists. Motorcyclists should never assume that drivers of larger vehicles will yield the right-of-way, even if they are legally required to do so.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, a motorcycle responds to directional changes:
questions.answerC: Normally.
questions.explanation: A passenger places extra weight on a motorcycle. Because of the added weight, the motorcycle will respond to the operator's movements more slowly than it would otherwise, taking more time to speed up, slow down, and turn.

questions.question: As your motorcycle increases speed, you will:
questions.answerA: Need to shift up through the gears.
questions.answerB: Need to shift down through the gears.
questions.answerC: Need to put the motorcycle into neutral.
questions.explanation: It is necessary to shift into higher gears as your motorcycle increases its speed.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast can cause a rider to:
questions.answerA: Accidentally end up in another lane of traffic.
questions.answerC: Keep control of their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast may cause a rider to cross into another lane of traffic, or even leave the road entirely. It is important to slow down before entering a turn or curve.

questions.question: A difference between googles and a windshield is:
questions.answerA: Goggles will protect you from the wind, but a windshield won’t.
questions.answerB: A windshield will protect you from the wind, but goggles won't.
questions.answerC: A windshield will keep your eyes from watering better than goggles.
questions.explanation: Googles will protect your eyes from the wind, but most windshields will not. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: When riding at night, maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it can be difficult to judge distances in the dark, ride with a following distance of at least three seconds when traveling at night.

questions.question: When being passed, it is usually best for motorcyclists to be in which part of the lane?
questions.answerC: The left
questions.explanation: If you are being passed either from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing driver could place you both in a hazardous situation.

questions.question: If your front wheel locks while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the tire locked until your next stop.
questions.answerB: Continue squeezing the front brake lever.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and immediately re-apply it.
questions.explanation: If the front wheel locks up while you are braking, release the pressure from the front brake. Immediately re-apply pressure to the brake with controlled gradual pressure.

questions.question: When riding over grooved pavement in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Look down to watch for changes in the road surface.
questions.answerB: Keep your head and eyes up.
questions.answerC: Move to the edge of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Keep your head and eyes up when riding through a work zone. Ride slowly over the grooved pavement.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerC: Decrease your following distance.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: A rider's boots or shoes should:
questions.answerC: Be made of a soft, pliable material.
questions.explanation: For riding, choose footwear that is sturdy and high enough to cover and support your ankles. Soles should be made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.

questions.question: When being followed by a tailgater, you should:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass or slow down to allow for more space ahead of your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed by a tailgater, you should ride in a way that encourages them to pass you. Riding at a higher speed may only result in them tailgating you at a higher speed, increasing the danger.

questions.question: The safest part of the lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Changes depending on the situation.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Adjust your lane position as circumstances warrant.

questions.question: If another driver makes eye contact with you:
questions.answerA: You know that they have seen you.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t always mean they've actually seen you.
questions.answerC: They will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never rely on eye contact as an assurance that a driver has seen you. It is not uncommon for a driver to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to actually notice them.

questions.question: When making a U-turn:
questions.answerA: The front and rear brakes need to be used at the same time.
questions.answerB: Do not use the front brake because it could cause the bike to tip over.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake to increase stability of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: The front brake should not be used when making a U-turn because it could cause the bike to tip over. Instead, use the rear brake to control the speed of the bike in the U-turn.

questions.question: When being passed, moving to the part of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be farther away from the passing vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because it invites the other driver to move back into your lane too early.
questions.answerC: Is not encouraged or discouraged as it has no impact on safety.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is not advisable to move to the part of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may prompt the passing driver to move back into your lane too early.

questions.question: If a motorcycle is towing a trailer, the motorcyclist's following distance should:
questions.answerC: Be the same as it normally would be.
questions.explanation: A motorcyclist who is towing a trailer should increase their following distance. The added weight of the trailer means that the motorcycle will require more time to stop than it would otherwise.

questions.question: When passing a vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: May exceed the speed limit by 10 mph.
questions.answerB: Must not exceed the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Are required to ride faster than the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Passing must be completed within posted speed limits. Only pass another vehicle where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: To shift up to a higher gear, you must:
questions.answerA: Place your foot under the shift lever and lift.
questions.answerB: Place your foot over the shift lever and push.
questions.answerC: Use your thumb to move the lever.
questions.explanation: To shift up to a higher gear, position your foot under the shift lever and lift.

questions.question: When starting your motorcycle, the engine should be in:
questions.answerC: Third gear.
questions.explanation: Make sure your motorcycle's transmission is in neutral before you start the engine. Most motorcycles have a neutral indicator on the speedometer that lights up when the ignition switch is on and the cycle is in neutral.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of avoiding serious injury in a crash if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: A sweatshirt.
questions.explanation: Wearing a U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)-compliant helmet can help protect you against head and neck injuries in the event of a crash. A jacket made of leather or sturdy synthetic material can also protect you against injuries.

questions.question: Which brake is more powerful on a motorcycle?
questions.answerC: Both brakes are equally powerful.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful that the rear brake and can provide at least 70 percent of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a potentially slippery surface?
questions.answerC: Dry pavement
questions.explanation: Traction may be poor on surfaces such as wet, snowy, icy, or muddy pavement; gravel roads; lane markings; and steel plates and utility hole covers.

questions.question: You are most likely to get into a collision:
questions.answerC: Traveling on the expressway.
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between you and other traffic exists at intersections.

questions.question: A DOT-compliant helmet:
questions.answerA: Will severely restrict your ability to see.
questions.answerB: Will allow you to see adequately to both sides.
questions.answerC: Will prevent you from turning your head.
questions.explanation: The belief that a helmet will restrict a wearer's vision is misguided. Any helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards will allow the wearer to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding.

questions.question: Before starting out, you should make sure the fuel valve is:
questions.answerC: Covered.
questions.explanation: Before setting out on a ride, you should make sure that your motorcycle's fuel supply valve is open. If the fuel valve is closed, the engine may still start with the fuel that is remaining in the lines from a previous ride, but it will stall once the lines are empty.

questions.question: Reflective clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be worn only at night.
questions.answerB: Should be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Should be worn both day and night.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight, so wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing while riding is advised no matter the time of day.

questions.question: Increase your following distance if:
questions.answerC: It is sunny.
questions.explanation: You should increase your following distance if it will take your motorcycle longer than normal to stop, if you can't see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and other vehicles are likely to try to squeeze in front of you.

questions.question: Eye protection is:
questions.answerC: Only required for inexperienced motorcycle users.
questions.explanation: Georgia law requires a rider to wear eye protection when on a moving motorcycle. A full face shield provides a rider with the best possible protection.

questions.question: __________ can be a cause of collisions involving motorcycles.
questions.answerC: Communicating with other drivers
questions.explanation: Following too closely, or "tailgating," can be a major factor in collisions caused by motorcycles. When riding behind another vehicle, maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: What does an integrated braking system do?
questions.answerA: It links the front and rear brakes together when the rear brake is applied.
questions.answerB: It knows when to brake automatically by understanding your riding habits.
questions.answerC: It is connected to the gears and applies the brake when downshifting.
questions.explanation: Some motorcycles have integrated braking systems that link the front and rear brakes together when the rider applies the rear brake pedal. It is important to consult your owner's manual for details on your specific motorcycle's braking system.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should not rely only on their mirrors because:
questions.answerA: Sometimes mirrors can be dirty, limiting the motorcyclist's view.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles have blind spots.
questions.explanation: To remain aware of your surroundings, it is not enough to rely only on your mirrors. Motorcycles have blind spots just like any other vehicle.

questions.question: Instruct your passenger to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Mount the motorcycle after you start the engine.
questions.answerB: Sit as far back on the motorcycle as possible.
questions.answerC: Hold onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Keep their legs away from the muffler.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a ride, you should ask your passenger to mount the motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding you and hold onto the motorcycle's passenger handholds or onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep their legs away from the muffler, chains, and other moving parts.

questions.question: Hearing protection is:
questions.answerC: Recommended for all rides.
questions.explanation: Long-term exposure to wind and engine noise can damage your hearing, even if you wear a helmet. It is a good idea to use hearing protection every time you ride to help prevent hearing damage.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The mirrors provide a perfect view.
questions.answerB: The mirrors do not show your blind spots.
questions.answerC: The mirrors should not be used, except when parking.
questions.explanation: As with any other vehicle, the mirrors of a motorcycle have blind spots. Always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: If your front wheel locks while you are stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue to apply the front brake.
questions.answerB: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Immediately release the front brake, then re-apply the brake firmly.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while you are making a quick stop, release the front brake immediately and then re-apply it firmly. Use both the front and rear brakes if you need to stop quickly.

questions.question: When traveling in a group, riders should generally be:
questions.answerC: In a staggered formation.
questions.explanation: In general, a staggered formation is the best way for a group of riders to maintain close ranks while allowing adequate space cushions for each rider. A single-file formation is best when taking curves, turning, entering a highway, or exiting a highway.

questions.question: If you borrow a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume all controls are in the same location as they are on your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Immediately take it out on the highway.
questions.answerC: Get familiar with it in a controlled area.
questions.explanation: All motorcycles are at least somewhat different. Before riding a motorcycle that is new to you, take the time to learn where all of the controls are. Ride the motorcycle in a controlled area to get used to it before taking it out on the road.

questions.question: When riding, jackets and pants should:
questions.answerA: Fit loosely enough to allow the wind to catch the fabric.
questions.answerB: Be snug enough to keep from flapping in the wind.
questions.answerC: Be tight enough to prevent you from moving freely.
questions.explanation: Jackets and pants should fit snugly enough that they do not flap in the wind, but also loosely enough that you are able to move freely.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should be sure not to:
questions.answerA: Keep their knees against the gas tank while riding.
questions.answerB: Keep their feet firmly on the footrests while riding.
questions.answerC: Adjust the handlebars so their hands are above their elbows.
questions.explanation: Adjust the handlebars so your hands are even with or below your elbows. This positioning allows you to use the proper muscles for precision steering. Keep your feet on the footrests and your knees against the gas tank to help you maintain your balance when turning.

questions.question: Use your mirrors when stopping at an intersection:
questions.answerA: To determine if drivers behind you are aware that you are stopping.
questions.answerC: To look for dark clouds that may indicate poor weather conditions.
questions.explanation: It is important to consistently check vehicles approaching your motorcycle from behind to determine if drivers are paying attention to you and your movements. Use your mirrors when stopping at an intersection to make sure approaching drivers are responding appropriately to your actions.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Protects your face, but not your eyes.
questions.answerB: Protects your eyes, but not your whole face.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides maximum protection for your entire face, including your eyes, in the event of a crash. A windshield is not an adequate substitute.

questions.question: To minimize the potential for fatigue on a long trip, you should:
questions.answerC: Play loud music.
questions.explanation: When taking a long trip, be sure to schedule in frequent breaks to rest, even if you do not feel tired. Experienced operators seldom try to ride for longer than six hours a day. Wind, cold, and rain can make you tire quickly, so be sure to dress to protect yourself from the elements.

questions.question: The gearshift is located:
questions.answerC: By the right handle grip.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best formation for keeping riders together while maintaining adequate space cushions is generally:
questions.answerC: A staggered formation.
questions.explanation: In general, the best way for a group of motorcyclists to maintain close ranks while still allowing each rider an adequate space cushion is to ride in a staggered formation.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply controlled pressure to both the front and rear brakes at the same time.

questions.question: On a motorcycle, which brake provides the most stopping power?
questions.answerC: The emergency brake
questions.explanation: The front brake provides about three-quarters of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both the front and rear brakes every time you stop.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your mirrors and look over your shoulder.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors. You do not need to look over your shoulder unless you notice something unusual.
questions.answerC: Either use your mirrors or look over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, make sure no other drivers are going to be in your path. Do this by checking your mirrors and looking over your shoulder in the direction you want to move.

questions.question: A properly adjusted rearview mirror should:
questions.answerA: Show the road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Not show any part of your body.
questions.answerC: Only show the road behind you, not any of the lane to the side.
questions.explanation: Your rearview mirror should be adjusted to display the road behind and to the side of your motorcycle. A properly adjusted mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop your motorcycle until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerB: Approach the animal slowly, then quickly accelerate away from the dog as it approaches.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.explanation: If you see a dog approaching your motorcycle, slow down and downshift until you are close to the dog. Quickly accelerate away from the animal as it approaches.

questions.question: Motorcycles may pass on the right:
questions.answerA: If there is at least eight feet of unobstructed pavement.
questions.answerB: By riding on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerC: By riding on the grass, if it is level.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists may pass on the right if there is unobstructed pavement with a width of at least eight feet to the right of the vehicle being passed. Motorcyclists, and other drivers, should never leave the road to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: Helmets are:
questions.answerC: Only required for inexperienced motorcycle users.
questions.explanation: Georgia law requires riders to wear U.S. Department of Transportation-compliant helmets every time they ride. A helmet is a rider's best defense against head and neck injuries in the event of an accident.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Provide a narrow view of the road behind you.
questions.answerB: Provide a wide view of the road behind you.
questions.answerC: Are illegal.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. Take the time to get used to your mirrors if your motorcycle is equipped with convex mirrors.

questions.question: For motorcycle operators, helmets are:
questions.answerC: Not recommended.
questions.explanation: In Georgia, you are required to wear a U.S. Department of Transportation-compliant helmet any time you operate a motorcycle.

questions.question: Usually a good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Ride faster.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle tailgaters is usually to change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: If you are being passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, the center portion of the lane is generally the safest lane position for a motorcyclist. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with it. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle can also be dangerous because it may prompt the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Your motorcycle should fit you, meaning:
questions.answerA: Your fingertips should barely reach the handlebars when you are seated on the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: The seat should be one foot higher than your waist when you are standing next to the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Your feet should comfortably reach the ground when you are seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle fits you appropriately if your feet comfortably reach the ground while you are seated. Be sure a motorcycle fits you before riding.

questions.question: If you will be carrying a passenger on your motorcycle, you will likely have to:
questions.answerC: Increase the tire pressure.
questions.explanation: Because a passenger will place additional weight on your motorcycle, you will probably need to add a few pounds of pressure to your tires before riding. Check your owner's manual for details regarding the appropriate pressure settings to use.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerC: Pull to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.explanation: When it starts to rain, the oily strip down the center of a lane is especially hazardous. Avoid this danger by riding in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track is often safest, but this can vary.

questions.question: What type of footwear is the best for motorcycle riders?
questions.answerC: Sandals
questions.explanation: Leather boots provide the best degree of protection when riding. They should be high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles.

questions.question: To reduce the chances of a collision, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerC: Ride the centerline.
questions.explanation: To reduce your chances of being involved in a collision, always allow yourself an adequate cushion of space. Maintain your space cushion when following another vehicle, being followed by another vehicle, passing, being passed, or lane sharing.

questions.question: It is illegal to operate a motorcycle with a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of:
questions.answerC: 0.3 percent.
questions.explanation: In California, it is illegal for a person age 21 or older to operate a motorcycle with a blood alcohol content (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. For a person under the age of 21, it is illegal to operate a motorcycle with a BAC of 0.01 percent or higher. It may be unsafe to operate a motorcycle even if you are under the legal limit.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes occur:
questions.answerC: At night.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. Wearing bright colors and reflective materials is always recommended when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: The best clothing for a motorcyclist:
questions.answerC: Should not stand out to other motorists.
questions.explanation: Properly chosen clothing for riding provides a rider with protection in the event of a crash while keeping the rider comfortable and ensuring that they are visible to other road users.

questions.question: To reduce the chances of a collision, you should:
questions.answerC: Focus only on your riding, not on your surroundings.
questions.explanation: Wearing bright or reflective clothing can help make you more visible to other drivers and reduce your risk of being involved in a collision. Always maintain an awareness of surrounding drivers to better prepare yourself for their movements.

questions.question: When riding, you should wear:
questions.answerC: Clothes that are uncomfortable.
questions.explanation: Wear brightly-colored clothing to maximize your visibility when riding, even during the daytime. Clothing made with reflective materials can also be helpful.

questions.question: To swerve correctly, you should:
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To swerve away from a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the handgrip located on the side of your intended escape.

questions.question: Which of the following factors may affect the blood alcohol content (BAC) of a person?
questions.answerC: The temperature outside
questions.explanation: The three major factors that can affect a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) are the amount of alcohol they have consumed, how quickly they consumed it, and the drinker's body weight.

questions.question: Blind spots on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Should be consistently checked by riders.
questions.answerC: Don't exist if the motorcycle has a rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Just like any other vehicle, motorcycles have blind spots. A rider should always turn their head to check for traffic in their blind spot before changing lanes. It is a good idea for a rider to make head checks a part of their normal routine.

questions.question: The center portion of the lane:
questions.answerB: Has an accumulation of oil and grease but usually provides enough traction for safe riding.
questions.answerC: Does not allow other motorists to see you in most instances.
