questions.explanation: Drippings from cars tend to accumulate in an oily strip in the center of each lane. This area usually still offers enough traction for safe motorcycle operation, unless it is raining.

questions.question: What does this sign mean?
questions.answerC: Merge
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions. This sign warns of merging traffic ahead.

questions.question: When traveling at night, it is:
questions.answerA: Easier to judge distances than it is during the day.
questions.answerB: About as easy to judge distances as it is during the day.
questions.answerC: More difficult to judge distances than it is during the day.
questions.explanation: It is almost always more difficult to judge distances when traveling in the dark than it is when traveling in daylight. Shadows and light contrasts are important cues to the distance of an object. When you must rely on artificial lighting to see the roadway at night, natural contrasts and shadows may be distorted or entirely absent.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Put their feet on the ground when the motorcycle is stopped.
questions.answerB: Not ride without a back rest.
questions.answerC: Sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator.
questions.explanation: A passenger on a motorcycle should sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator. The passenger should keep both feet on the footrests at all times, even when stopped.

questions.question: You approach an emergency vehicle that is stopped on the side of the road while using its flashing lights. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop on the roadway behind the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop and wait until the emergency vehicle begins moving again.
questions.answerC: Merge into a lane away from the emergency vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you approach an emergency vehicle, tow truck, or roadside assistance vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing, you must change lanes to allow the vehicle extra space and proceed with caution. Always slow down and be prepared to stop when you approach an emergency scene.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used in an emergency.
questions.answerB: Should be used with the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Is unsafe to use.
questions.explanation: You should always use both brakes when you slow or stop.

questions.question: When sitting on a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your arms to hold up your body.
questions.answerB: Sit at an angle so your arms can support your weight.
questions.answerC: Sit so you can use your arms to control the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Sit with a posture that allows you to use your arms to control your motorcycle. You should not be positioned in a way that requires your arms to prop up your body and support your weight.

questions.question: Riding on ______ may provide poor traction.
questions.answerC: The roadway under a bridge
questions.explanation: Traction may be poor on surfaces such as wet, snowy, icy, or muddy pavement; gravel roads; lane markings; and steel plates and utility hole covers.

questions.question: If you are riding behind another vehicle at night, you can determine if there are bumps on the road ahead by:
questions.answerA: Listening for the other vehicle scraping against the pavement.
questions.answerB: Noticing the other vehicle’s taillights bouncing up and down.
questions.answerC: Looking at the rear bumper of the vehicle ahead and trying to determine if it is bouncing.
questions.explanation: To determine upcoming road conditions when riding at night, use the vehicle ahead of you. For example, the headlights of the vehicle may provide a better view of the road than your own high beam. If the vehicle's taillights bounce up and down, this indicates the presence of bumps on the road.

questions.question: Under normal riding conditions, one of the best ways to help others see your motorcycle is:
questions.answerB: To keep your high beam headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: To ensure that your motorcycle is painted a dark color.
questions.explanation: The best way to help others see your motorcycle is to have your headlight turned on (as well as your running lights, if applicable). Use your high beam headlight both day and night, whenever it is legal and safe to do so.

questions.question: To make it easier to be seen by other motorists, you should:
questions.answerC: Wave your arms while riding.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing while riding will make it easier for others on the road to see you. This is true regardless of the time of day.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between you and other vehicles?
questions.answerC: On any road
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between motorcycles and other traffic is at intersections. Oncoming cars turning left in front of motorcyclists is the biggest danger.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Encourage other drivers to share your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: The Motorcycle Safety Foundation recommends a SEE strategy to make safe judgments while riding. What does "SEE" stand for?
questions.answerC: Safe, Experienced, and Evasive.
questions.explanation: Experienced riders use a SEE strategy while riding to make safe judgements. "SEE" stands for Search, Evaluate, and Execute.

questions.question: Of the following, it is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: Someone is following you too closely.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.explanation: Because a motorcycle's brake light is not as noticeable as the brake lights of a car, it is usually a good idea to flash your brake light when slowing or stopping so others will be more likely to notice that you are decelerating. This is particularly important if you are slowing down more quickly than others might expect.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to get over the surface faster.
questions.answerB: Exaggerate the zigzag motion to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed and ride straight across the grooves or gratings.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle begins to weave when riding over grooves or gratings, simply maintain a steady speed and proceed straight across the surface. Trying to compensate for the weave by riding at an angle forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane, which is more dangerous.

questions.question: Wearing which of the following colors will make you less visible to other motorists?
questions.answerC: Brown
questions.explanation: To make yourself more visible to other road users, it is best if you choose to wear bright orange, red, yellow, or green clothing. Avoid wearing drab or dark colors while riding.

questions.question: What does a flashing red traffic light mean?
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop and proceed when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Only stop to yield to other traffic.
questions.answerC: Vehicles will be entering the roadway.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to all crossing traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: The front brake supplies about how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerC: About three-quarters
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide three-quarters of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: When selecting a jacket that will be used as protective apparel, a motorcycle rider should look for a jacket that is:
questions.answerC: Made of leather or synthetic materials.
questions.explanation: When riding a motorcycle, it is highly recommended that you wear protective apparel. Look for a jacket that completely covers your arms and fits snugly but still allows you to move freely. Leather or sturdy synthetic materials with integrated body armor offer the best protection.

questions.question: What should be your first consideration when buying a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerC: Price
questions.explanation: Protection should be your first consideration when buying a motorcycle helmet. Look for a helmet that fastens securely, fits correctly, and is DOT-compliant.

questions.question: You should maintain an increased following distance:
questions.answerC: If you can see through the vehicles in front of you to determine traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum four-second following distance.

questions.question: Where should you position your motorcycle when entering a curve?
questions.answerC: Wherever traffic and road conditions require
questions.explanation: All curves are different. When taking a curve, choose a lane position that is appropriate for conditions and adjust as needed.

questions.question: To minimize the potential for fatigue, you should:
questions.answerC: Drink caffeine.
questions.explanation: Taking frequent rest breaks during a long trip can help reduce fatigue. Stimulants, such as caffeine, can ultimately increase the danger of fatigue because you may become extremely tired when they begin to wear off. Wind, rain, snow, and other elements can also increase levels of fatigue, so dress warmly (as needed) and invest in a windshield, especially if you plan to ride long distances.
